title: 111_s2983
content: The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows for payroll tax forgiveness for hiring unemployed workers. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" provides a special exemption for certain individuals hired in 2010, allowing qualified employers to not pay wages for services performed by qualified individuals during that year. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" exempts qualified employers from paying wages to qualified individuals hired between February 3, 2010, and January 1, 2011. Qualified employers are defined as any employer except the United States, States, local governments, or their instrumentalities. Qualified individuals must certify their employment with a qualified employer through a signed affidavit. Qualified individuals, for this subsection, are those who start working for a qualified employer between February 3, 2010, and January 1, 2011, have not worked more than 40 hours in the 60 days before starting, are not replacing another employee unless they left voluntarily or for cause, and are not individuals specified in another section. Qualified individuals must meet specific criteria to be eligible for this subsection, including not replacing another employee unless they left voluntarily or for cause. Employers can elect to opt-out of this provision. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes coordination with the Work Opportunity Credit and payroll tax forgiveness. Wages paid to qualified individuals by qualified employers may not be included unless the employer elects not to apply section 3111(d). Appropriations are made to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. The amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 involve coordination with the Work Opportunity Credit and payroll tax forgiveness. Qualified employers may elect not to apply section 3111(d) to wages paid to qualified individuals. Appropriations are made to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. The amendments apply to wages paid after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Business credit for retention of certain newly hired individuals in 2010. The business credit for retention of certain newly hired individuals in 2010 increases the current year business credit by $1,000 for each retained worker who meets specific criteria. A retained worker is defined as a qualified individual employed by the taxpayer for at least 52 consecutive weeks with wages paid during the last 26 weeks.
